In a closely-contested election
William Reid, a student in the
School of Engineering, defeated
Caleb Kelly, a member of the College of Arts and Sciences, for the

Reid Athlete

Reid has been an outstanding
member of the swimming team for
the past two seasons and is at present holder of the South Atlantic
low-board diving championship. He
has been defeated only twice in his
collegiate career and as a result of

1933 J. H. U. swimming team.

limited only to swimming. Although
he is not generally conceded to be a
brilliant football player, he has
proved a valuable man for the Jay
defense for the past two grid campaigns.

Conrad Gebelein
Elected President
Of Music Guild
Conrad Gebelein, prominent Baltimore musician and director of the
J. H. U. Band and instrumental
groups in the Musical Club, has
been selected as head of the American Guild of Banjoists,• Mandolinists, and Guitarists, it was learned
recently. He was elected for the
year 1932-33 by the organization
at its last annual convention held in
Washington.
Locally Prominent

Having followed a profesisonal
career for a number of years past,
Gebelein is regarded locally as an
authority on stringed instruments.
He has directed the activity of the
Banjo Club and Hawaiian Troupe,
Musical Club divisions, for a number of consecutive seasons, and has
resumed his association with them
and with the Hopkins Band, which
he directed last season for the first
time.
Composed Hopkins March

The musician has secured recognition particularly through his
compositions and arrangements.
Principal among the former are his
March WBAL, dedicated to the local radio station, and March J. H.
U., which was publicly played for
the first time by the Banjo Club in
its programs of last year.
Student Instrumentalists Wanted

Students at the University who
play any of the stringed instruments are invited to join Gebelein's
Musical Club groups, which meet
for rehearsal on Thursday nights
at 9 o'clock, in Room B, Levering
Hall.

Langfeld Is Named
Asst. Managing Editor
Owing to the inability of Sanford
Sarney, '33, to carry out all the duties required of an assistant managing editor because of his heavy
schedule of studies, Millard Langfeld, of the Class of 1934, has been
chosen to fill the post. He is to be
in charge of the issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER which appears Friday morning.
Sarney is to serve as an associate editor.

As a method of balancing the
budget, as well as to insure the injection of new blood in the faculty
and to combat the possibility of dry
rot, Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president
of the John Hopkins University,
yesterday recommended to the
Board of Trustees a far-reaching
reorganization in the various departments which would organize the J.
H. U. faculty on a basis not known
to be in use in any American university.
Dr. Ames believes that the Board
of Trustees should advise the President before the beginning of the
fiscal year what funds are available
for the budget of each school in the
University. The President and faculties would then prepare the budgets to meet these financial limitations, he indicated.
Would Limit Appointments

The President, moreover, would
have every member of the faculty
below the grade of full professor
appointed for a limited term, with
no new appointments to be made
unless there are vacancies, and no
new positions created unless new
endowment funds. are available, he
told the Trustees yesterday.
In order to secure new men on
the staff, he would provide for limited terms of appointment for men
below the rank of professor. Dr.
Ames reported that he would have
the University adopt the policy of
encouraging its younger faculty
members, in their interest as well as
the University's, to seek university
employment elsewhere, because he
believes that the broadened experience so gained will make them
more valuable in case they are called
back later, as a few of them certainly will be.
Recommends Increased Teaching Load

The Hopkins president recommends the policy of increasing the
teaching load when a faculty member has reached the age of fifty-five,
in order to release younger men for
research work. He would combat
the idea, he said, that promotions
in the faculty are, or that they
should be, automatic, and he advocates the fixing of a minimum salary for professors and a maximum
salary for other grades. Dr. Ames
advocates compulsory retirement at
the age of seventy.

We make that assertion without any
fear of contradiction and with no personal slander of either the new president of the Senior Class or Freshman
Class or of the nominees for the executive post in the Sophomore Class. We
speak the truth, we are certain.
Each member of the classes and the
fraternities involved in the disgusting,
disgraceful game of vote-combines is to
blame for the condition which now exists. We neither assert nor deny that
Reid or Simpson won the elections by
skillful politics. If they did, it was because of the lethargic attitude of those
non-fraternity men who failed to place
a candidate in the field who is untainted
by fraternity politics. There is no objection to a fraternity man getting into
office, provided he deserves the honor.
Inasmuch as there is with fraternities
mixed in with campus activities the existence of combines, cliques, and politics,
it is highly essential that the non-fraternity men wake up, show an interest,
and make every effort to break the rule
of the fraternity politicians in class and
activity elections.
If a man cannot win on his merit as
a man alone and not as a good politician, he does not deserve to be named
to head the class of which he is a member. If the classes cannot select a man
who has shown an interest in campus
affairs, honesty, straightforwardness,
ability, and efficiency without having to
make combines to carry an election, then
the only solution is to abolish class officers and place the affairs of the classes
in the hands of a faculty committee.
The standards of campus elections here
must be raised—and as soon as possible.
The practice of predesignation of class
officers through fraternity combines is a
disgraceful and unrepresentative one
which must be abolished.

As a method of balancing the
budget, as well as to insure the injection of new blood in the faculty
and to combat the possibility of dry
rot, Dr. Joseph S. Ames, president
of the John Hopkins University,
yesterday recommended to the
Board of Trustees a far-reaching
reorganization in the various departments which would organize the J.
H. U. faculty on a basis not known
to be in use in any American university.
Dr. Ames believes that the Board
of Trustees should advise the President before the beginning of the
fiscal year what funds are available
for the budget of each school in the
University. The President and faculties would then prepare the budgets to meet these financial limitations, he indicated.
Would Limit Appointments

The President, moreover, would
have every member of the faculty
below the grade of full professor
appointed for a limited term, with
no new appointments to be made
unless there are vacancies, and no
new positions created unless new
endowment funds. are available, he
told the Trustees yesterday.
In order to secure new men on
the staff, he would provide for limited terms of appointment for men
below the rank of professor. Dr.
Ames reported that he would have
the University adopt the policy of
encouraging its younger faculty
members, in their interest as well as
the University's, to seek university
employment elsewhere, because he
believes that the broadened experience so gained will make them
more valuable in case they are called
back later, as a few of them certainly will be.
Recommends Increased Teaching Load

The Hopkins president recommends the policy of increasing the
teaching load when a faculty member has reached the age of fifty-five,
in order to release younger men for
research work. He would combat
the idea, he said, that promotions
in the faculty are, or that they
should be, automatic, and he advocates the fixing of a minimum salary for professors and a maximum
salary for other grades. Dr. Ames
advocates compulsory retirement at
the age of seventy.

The specified tenure of each of the
other grades is one year; but this obviously means nothing and each man
confidently expects re-appointment;
and, in fact, I think each associate professor considers his tenure of office
as secure as that of a professor. The
grades in the Faculty of Philosophy at
present are professor, associate professor, associate instructor.
There is not the slightest uniformity
in the salaries of those in any one
grade; and as a consequence each man
on the faculty feels free to ask for
an increase in salary each year, and
each professor feels free to urge such
increases for the younger men on his
staff. There is, therefore, constant
pressure to raise all salaries.
Cites Logical Consequences
The logical consequences of this
practically permanent tenure of office
and of the pressure to promote from
one grade to another and to increase
salaries are as follows:
1. The University will have on
its faculty all those men who
are not called to other institutions.
2. There will be only professors.
3. There will be no money to add
new men to the staff.
The entire situation seems to me to
be wrong and to be one of the reasons
for the present financial condition.

Five specific recommendations
then follow. They are: (1) to reduce the number of grades to three
—professor and two others; (2) to
continue the tenure of office of a
professor as indefinite,. but to make
that of the other two grades five
years, with "the express understanding that only in the higher of these
is a man eligible for re-appointment
and then only as an exception"; (3)
to determine the salary of each professorship and consider it fixed, except for special considerations, and
to fix minimum and maximum salaries for the other two grades, the
maximum to be approached by increases of $100. each year; (4) to
adopt for the appointment of men
to the higher of the two grades the
same procedure now employed for
the appointment of professors; (5)
to allocate to each department a definite part of the total sum available
for salaries, and thereafter to make
promotions and appointments in that
department only when additional
funds shall be available.

adopted," remarked Dr. Ames, "it
